attributes.action: Scrap Energy Standing Charges
attributes.background:
Remove the standing charges from energy bills. These charges have increased heavily recently.
Costs to cover failed companies and green energy plans should be linked to consumption.
attributes.additional_details: When people reduce their use to save money, they still pay a heavy amount due to the standing charges. These are paid by all, regardless of how much, or how little, energy is used. This makes it hard to reduce bills, even when cutting back on usage. Standing charges are unfair.

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about standing charges are a matter for utility providers and Ofgem, not the UK Government or Parliament.

The price cap is a cap on a unit of gas and electricity, with standing charges taken into account. Find out more about the energy price cap, including how it includes standing charges, here: https://www.ofgem.gov.uk/check-if-energy-price-cap-affects-you

attributes.action: Sell houses of parliament & move government to more modern UK central location
attributes.background: The palace of Westminster needs repairing; the cost of £22 BILLION far too heavy a burden for public purse. The buildings should be sold to the private sector. Proceeds used to create a new parliament in UK central location, with rest of money used to help create new national public energy company.
attributes.additional_details: 90% of British citizens live outside of London, with the average median wage outside of London being 25% lower. The internet has changed the face of democracy, allowing the public to become far more hands on in having a say in the way our nation is run & we want to break away from the past archaic methods that we feel hold back our democracy in an antiquated manner. Parliament should be moved to a modern online UK central (Derbyshire/Manchester) building, rather than its London rebuild from 1876

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you want the House of Parliament to be sold, and a new parliament established elsewhere, but it's not clear what you mean by an "online" building, or whether you want other changes to how the Government and Parliament operate.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Force companies who draw oil/gas from UK waters to sell to us at a reduced rate.
attributes.background: Pass an emergency law with a "set time frame" to force companies that are drawing fossil fuels from UK waters to sell all or part of it to the UK market at a reduced rate. BP and others then still earn profits but not at a extreme level which is currently putting many households into energy poverty.
attributes.additional_details: Speak with these companies first to see if an agreement can be reached OR pass a law to force it through. Emergency laws are being used by other countries in times of need just like on wheat and food oils so we need to do the same to protect out most vulnerable. I think a one off windfall tax is just that, a one off.. We need a slightly longer term plan to support UK citizens. We could even agree a % to be sold at a reduced rate so the government can just target low income households?

rejection.details:
We understand you would like companies to be forced to sell oil and gas produced in the UK at a reduced rate, however it's not clear if you want this to apply to the sale of oil and gas to wholesalers, or to the sale of energy generated using these fuels to consumers, or both.

You could have a petition calling on the Government to impose a price cap on energy generated using fossil fuels produced in the UK, if that is something you'd like to see happen.

Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

attributes.action: Remove the tax-payer funded subsidy from House of Commons dining and bars.
attributes.background: With food prices rocketing and energy costs set to rise again in the autumn, many people are struggling to feed their families, and yet The House of Commons continues to subsidise the prices in it’s dining rooms, restaurants and bars, using tax-payer money.
attributes.additional_details: We call upon the government, and the MPs of The House of Commons to address the disparity between the lives of ordinary people, and our elected representatives. Surely, during this time of widespread financial hardship, it is time for those both in power and opposition to take measures that demonstrate we really are “all in this together”.

rejection.details:
The House of Commons Catering service does not provide a subsidised service in the commercial sense of the word. Some venues make a profit, while in other venues the cost of providing the service does exceed the income received in sales due to the irregular hours and unpredictability of parliamentary business. The House of Commons publishes details of the cost of House of Commons catering services: https://www.parliament.uk/site-information/foi/transparency-publications/hoc-transparency-publications/catering-services/transparency-reporting-catering-services/

Customers of the House of Commons Catering Services include some of the 650 MPs but also around 14,500 other pass-holders, many of whom are staff on lower wages that work irregular hours. In addition, members of the public and non pass holding visitors to Parliament also have access to these services. The irregular hours and the unpredictability of Parliamentary business contribute to increasing the net cost of providing a catering service. To offset this many of the restaurants, dining room facilities and their staff, are used to cater for private events at times when they are not required by the House. This is one of a number of measures used to reduce costs.

We could accept a petition calling for prices of food and drink in the House of Commons to be increased, either for all users or for Members of Parliament, if that's what you'd like to see happen.

attributes.action: Review the Method for Calculating the Energy Price Cap
attributes.background: Consider the benefits of applying a 'volume pricing' model which is linked to council tax bands, for example:
attributes.additional_details:
Those living in council tax band F, are charged 5p per kWh per month for the first 500 kwh, increasing to 7p per kWh per month, for the next 250 kwh, increasing to 9p per kWh per month for the next 250 kwh..... etc

Those living in council tax band H, are charged 9p per kWh per month for the first 500 kwh, increasing to 12p per kWh per month, for the next 250 kwh, increasing to 15p per kWh per month for the next 250 kwh..... etc

This method of pricing rewards those who use less encouraging people to reduce consumption, and it allows those whose assets indicate they can afford more, to subsidise those whose assets indicate they may struggle.

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

The energy price cap is set by Ofgem, not the Government or Parliament, but we could accept a petition calling on the Government to give Ofgem powers to set a variable price cap based on usage, rather than a fixed price cap.

attributes.action: Pass a windfall tax on gas and energy firms such as Shell and BP.
attributes.background: BP and Shell have reported profits of $12.8bn and $19.3bn. There has been no significant tax on these profits.
attributes.additional_details:
Investment in clean energy by oil and gas companies was about 1% of their capital expenditure in 2020, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA)
BP reported a profit of $12.8bn (£9.4bn) for last year, following Shell’s announcement last week of $19.3bn in profits. 
BP has paid no tax on its North Sea oil and gas for five years.

The thinly veiled excuse of using the capital to reinvest into green energy is unjustifiable as they would have already been committed to these projects regardless. There is no way to make them accountable for a non contractual premise and these companies are still investing in gas and oil exploration which would be disingenuous with the global climate targets to prevent a temperature rise above 1.5C.

attributes.background: I urge the government to scrap the Energy Bills Rebate to be replaced with an optional arrangement or something else entirely. This is a policy which appears will have the complete opposite effect of what is intended and I believe it needs to be more thoroughly considered or withdrawn completely.
attributes.additional_details:
What is proposed, is to solve the cost of living crisis by increasing every household’s energy bills for 5 years. 
The £200 suggested will go unnoticed by most, and many providers will allow more than this in debit, so there is no need for government intervention. In the longer term this will adversely affect the worst off with very little upfront benefit. This is essentially, a forced debt on every household, which is baffling and will only exacerbate the cost of living problem in future.

attributes.background: A suspension in the renewable energy tariff would help to take a great burden off the working population. I am currently on state pension  and like many others in this country I have paid my dues without question and deserve to reap the benefit of our hard work over 51 years.

attributes.action: Stop energy suppliers who get 100% from renewable sources inflating their prices
attributes.background:
Ensure that Electricity Price Capping reflects a green energy strategy and supports the users who always choose providers using renewable sources.
The price of gas cannot be a reason to increase the price of energy from renewable sources
attributes.additional_details: The renewables industry is full of private investors all claiming that prices of electricity from wind, solar, tide or other sources that belong to us all, will reduce over time. Government and or Parliament needs to recognise at the domestic / residential level the choice we have made to be "Green" and prevent profiteering.

rejection.details:
The prices charged for the use of energy by domestic customers, within the limits allowed by the energy price cap, are a matter for individual utility companies, not the UK Government or Parliament.

You could have a petition calling on the Government to create a renewable energy price cap, if that is something you'd like to see happen.

attributes.action: All businesses, shops and offices to switch off their lights when unoccupied.
attributes.background: There are a significant number of business and large buildings seemingly unoccupied with all of the main interior lighting still switched on. Lighting inside businesses and large unoccupied complexes is a huge, unnecessary waste of electricity.
attributes.additional_details:
Turning off lights when a building or area is unoccupied could save millions per year and reduce carbon emissions. 
Approximately 10% (6.5 million) of us regularly leave lights on when not in a room. Based on industry averages, this equates to an estimated £14,950,000 of wasted energy per day across the UK, and £3,619,000 whilst we sleep. 
This creates 37,440,000 kg of carbon dioxide emissions, or what would be the equivalent of 62 flights around the world each day. At night it’s 8,985,600 kg.

attributes.additional_details: Currently a log burner is being used, not eco friendly not good for the environment, but the storage heaters lose all their heat and blow all day running up fuel costs we can't afford due to heat loss, so we don't run them. It's the environment or we get cold. We need new Windows now, not just for home owners for long term tenants.

Please keep your promise for once.

attributes.action: Remove Tfl Ulez compliant cameras in poor communities in South East London
attributes.background: Government approach to address air pollution in communities can not be generalised as communities differ in terms of their needs. I will enjoin Government to do the following in poor communities to address air pollution and improve quality of lives of the inhabitants.
attributes.additional_details:
1. A campaign that will encourage green building 
2. A campaign that will encourage people to ride a bike or walking instead of driving.
3. A campaign that will encourage taking a bus or carpooling. 
4. A campaign that will promote the use of energy efficient light bulbs and appliances. 
5. A campaign that will encourage people to turn 6. Government should focus on renewable fuel 
6.A campaign that will encourage people to buy fewer things that are manufactured using fossil fuels.

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about the ULEZ and local advertising for public transport are a matter for Transport for London and the London Assembly, not the UK Government or House of Commons. As a result it is not possible for the Government or House of Commons to take the action you have requested.

The London Assembly has its own petitions process. You can find out more about how to petition the London Assembly here: https://www.london.gov.uk/about-us/london-assembly/petitions

We could accept a petition calling on the Government to run national campaigns on some of the things you outline in your list.

attributes.action: Subsidise renewable energy production, not fossil fuel extraction
attributes.background: Following on from COP26, introduce a full programme of  government subsidies for renewable energy production and eliminate subsidies for fossil fuel extraction.
attributes.additional_details: It's already been agreed worldwide that the single biggest action needed to deal with the climate crisis is to reduce fossil fuel use and promote renewable energy. It's not rocket science. If the UK government made this switch in its subsidies programme tomorrow, the carbon based giant producers would be holding top level meetings the following day to urgently change their policies to renewables. And it would be just as good for business. Thank you.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you want the Government to change how it funds the energy sector, but it's not clear what you mean by a "full programme of government subsidies for renewable energy production". The Government already provides funding for renewable generation, and it's not clear how you want this to change.

We can accept petitions calling for the Government to end financial suport for fossil fuels, although the Government says that it does give any subsidies to fossil fuels.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: introduce a carbon dividend levied on imports and given to consumers
attributes.background: The carbon footprint of goods entering the UK needs to be accounted for. Import duty should be levied according to the carbon footprint of goods entering the country. The revenue generated could be passed on to consumers as a dividend so that we are no worse off than before.
attributes.additional_details: By distributing the levy as a dividend, consumers as a whole would have no net cost of any increase in prices. Nevertheless, those consumers who choose goods with a lower carbon footprint would be better off. In addition, the costs of decarbonising the UK energy supply would no longer disadvantage UK industry compared to the importers of goods manufactured in countries relying heavily on coal and other fossil fuels.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you want to see changes to how imports are taxed, but we're not sure exactly how you want any levy and dividend to work. Your petition refers to people being no worse off than before, but then also says that people who choose goods with a lower carbon footprint would be better off. It is therefore not clear how you want any levy and dividend to operate.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.
